general: The Finance Act 2000 is a law passed by the UK government to change taxes and how the country's debt and revenue are managed. It includes provisions for new taxes, changes to existing taxes, and updates to the laws about national debt and public revenue. The goal of the act is to ensure the financial stability of the country and to raise revenue for the government.

series.short: "New UK Duty Rates for Alcoholic Beverages (2000)"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Finance Act 2000 increases the rate of duty on beer, cider, and wine/made-wine in the United Kingdom.
* Simplified point 2: For beer, the new rate of duty is set at £11.89 per hectolitre, effective as of April 1st, 2000.
* Simplified point 3: For cider, the new rates of duty are as follows:
	+ Sparkling cider of a strength exceeding 5.5%: £166.70 per hectolitre
	+ Cider of a strength exceeding 7.5% but not sparkling: £39.21 per hectolitre
	+ Any other case: £26.13 per hectolitre
* Simplified point 4: For wine and made-wine, the new rates of duty are as follows:
	+ Wine or made-wine of a strength not exceeding 22%: £47.58 per hectolitre
	+ Wine or made-wine of a strength exceeding 4% but not exceeding 5.5%: £65.42 per hectolitre
	+ Sparkling wine or sparkling made-wine of a strength exceeding 5.5% but less than 8.5%: £166.70 per hectolitre
	+ Sparkling wine or sparkling made-wine of a strength of 8.5% or of a strength exceeding 8.5% but not exceeding 15%: £220.54 per hectolitre
	+ Wine or made-wine of a strength exceeding 15% but not exceeding 22%: £205.82 per hectolitre
* Simplified point 5: These changes take effect on April 1st, 2000.

	+ £132.33 per kilogram for cigars

series.short: "Finance Act 2000 Update: Cigarette Duty Calculation Method Changes"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the Finance Act 2000 updates the method for calculating the ad valorem duty on cigarettes.
* Simplified point 2: The update involves using the higher of two prices - the recommended retail price and the price shown on the packaging - or the normal selling price in the UK if there is no recommended or shown price.
* Simplified point 3: The change aims to ensure that the duty is calculated based on the actual market price of cigarettes at the time of sale.

series.short: "UK Tobacco Product Regulations: Fiscal Marks and Enforcement Measures"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government can change the requirements for tobacco products' fiscal markings through secondary legislation without needing parliamentary approval.
* Simplified point 2: Fiscal marks must be carried by certain tobacco products, including cigarettes and hand-rolling tobacco, and the Commissioners can specify the details of these marks through regulations.
* Simplified point 3: Failure to comply with fiscal mark regulations can result in forfeiture of the products and civil penalties.
* Simplified point 4: Sale of unmarked tobacco products is illegal, and managers of premises who allow such sales can be fined and face premises closure orders.
* Simplified point 5: Altering or overprinting fiscal marks can attract penalties and forfeiture of the products.

series.short: "Tobacco Products Regulation: Excise Duty Management & Compliance Requirements"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Finance Act 2000 makes changes to the way excise duty is managed on tobacco products.
* Simplified point 2: The act allows for the remission or repayment of duty on tobacco products that are exported, shipped as stores, or used for research or experiment, provided that the fiscal marks on the products have been obliterated.
* Simplified point 3: The act also gives the commissioners the power to make regulations regarding the charging of duty on tobacco products, including the method of charging and the time at which the duty becomes payable.
* Simplified point 4: The act requires the registration of premises for the manufacture of tobacco products and regulates the storage and treatment of these products in, and removal from, such premises.
* Simplified point 5: The act allows for the imposition of conditions and restrictions on the matters mentioned in subsection (1), such as the notification of information and the making of returns.
* Simplified point 6: The act enables the commissioners to dispense with compliance with any provisions contained in the regulations in certain circumstances and subject to certain conditions.

series.short: "Gaming Duty Rates Overhaul in Finance Act 2000"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This extract of the Finance Act 2000 changes the rates of gaming duty for certain amounts of gross gaming yield.
* Simplified point 2: The new rates are 2.5% for the first £470,500, 12.5% for the next £1,045,500, 20% for the next £1,045,500, 30% for the next £1,830,000, and 40% for any amount above that.
* Simplified point 3: These changes apply to accounting periods beginning on or after April 1st, 2000.

series.short: UK Government Modifies Air Passenger Duty Rates
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government is modifying the Air Passenger Duty (APD) rates for flights starting on or after April 1, 2001.
* Simplified point 2: The modification involves changing the basis for determining the APD rate from "appropriate" to "determined in accordance with subsections (2) to (4) below."
* Simplified point 3: Under the new rules, the APD rate will depend on the class of travel and the destination of the flight. Standard class travel will be £5 if the passenger's agreement for carriage provides for standard class travel in relation to every flight on their journey, and £10 otherwise.
* Simplified point 4: The changes also exempt certain passengers from paying APD, such as those traveling on return journeys within the UK.
* Simplified point 5: The modifications apply to any carriage of a passenger on an aircraft beginning on or after April 1, 2001.

series.short: "UK Vehicle Excise Duty Changes: Threshold Increase & Refunds"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government is raising the threshold for the reduced rate of vehicle excise duty from 1,100cc to 1,200cc, effective March 1, 2001.
* Simplified point 2: The government will provide refunds to those who paid the lower rate of duty on licenses issued between March 1, 2000, and February 28, 2001, since their vehicles fall below the new threshold.
* Simplified point 3: The refund amount is £55 for a 12-month license and £27.50 for a 6-month license.
* Simplified point 4: The keeper of the vehicle is eligible for the refund, and they must apply in writing with proof of ownership and registration.
* Simplified point 5: The increased general rate of vehicle excise duty will go into effect on March 1, 2001, with the standard rate increasing from £155 to £160, and the reduced rate increasing from £100 to £105.
* Simplified point 6: New car and van owners will pay the higher rates of duty starting March 1, 2001, according to the schedule in the act.

series.short: "UK Customs Search Powers: Authority to Seize Dutiable Goods Without Warrant"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government has the power to search any premises without a warrant if there is suspicion of unpaid excise duty.
* Simplified point 2: The power to search premises without a warrant is only applicable when there is reasonable ground to suspect that anything liable to forfeiture under the customs and excise acts is kept or concealed in any building or place.
* Simplified point 3: The power to search premises without a warrant is limited to entering the building or place at any time, whether by day or night, on any day, and searching for, seizing, and detaining or removing any such thing.
* Simplified point 4: The power to search articles allows officials to search any article that a person has with them or at the place where they are, if there are reasonable grounds to suspect that the article contains dutiable alcoholic liquor or tobacco products.
* Simplified point 5: The security for customs and excise duties has been amended to include bonds and guarantees, and the expression "condition in connection with excise" now includes conditions in connection with excise duty charged under the law of a member state other than the United Kingdom.

series.short: "Climate Change Levy: Encouraging Carbon Reduction in Businesses"
series.text:
* The Climate Change Levy was introduced to encourage businesses to reduce their carbon emissions.
* The levy is a tax on energy used by businesses, and it applies to certain industries such as power generation, oil refining, and mineralogical processes.
* The schedule outlines the provisions for the levy, including registration requirements and consequences for non-compliance.
* The government has the authority to appoint a date for the levy to come into force, and different dates can be appointed for different purposes.

series.short: "Tax Rates and Credits in the UK for the Year 2000-01"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Finance Act 2000 sets out the income tax rates for the year 2000-01, including the starting rate, basic rate, and higher rate.
* Simplified point 2: The act introduces a new extension of the starting rate to savings income of individuals, allowing them to pay a lower rate of tax on their savings income.
* Simplified point 3: The act also makes changes to the deduction of income tax from foreign dividends, allowing for deductions at the Schedule F ordinary rate.
* Simplified point 4: The children's tax credit is increased to £4,420 for the year 2001-02 and subsequent years of assessment.
* Simplified point 5: Corporation tax is charged at a rate of 30% for the financial year 2001, while small companies' rate is set at 20% for the financial year 2000.
* Simplified point 6: Capital gains tax is subject to the starting rate, with individuals able to claim a lower rate of tax on their capital gains if their total income for the year is less than the starting rate limit.

series.short: "Employer Charitable Donations Law: Deductions, Supplements, and Record-Keeping Requirements"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This law allows employers to deduct certain amounts from employees' wages and give it to charities.
* Simplified point 2: The law requires the employer to pay a supplement of 10% of the deducted amount to the charity through an agent.
* Simplified point 3: The law also provides for the payment of supplements to agents who are themselves charities.
* Simplified point 4: The regulations can require agents to notify the board of any failure to comply with the law and keep records of supplements paid.
* Simplified point 5: The law applies to supplements payable in respect of sums withheld on or after 6th April 2000 and before 6th April 2003, and no claims will be entertained after 6th April 2004.

series.short: "New Rules for Gift Aid Payments in the UK: Changes to Record Keeping, Limits, and Tax Deductions"
series.text:
* The text describes changes to the rules regarding gift aid payments by individuals in the UK.
* The updates include new requirements for charities to keep records of donations and adjustments to the limits on the amount of gift aid that can be claimed based on the value of benefits received in return for the donation.
* The text also introduces a new definition of "qualifying donation" and provides for the recovery of excess tax deducted from gifts.
* Other changes include modifications to the calculation of income tax and capital gains tax for donors, and the elimination of certain tax reliefs.
* The updated rules will take effect starting April 6, 2000.

series.short: "Finance Act 2000 Amendments: Streamlined Gift Aid Payments for Companies"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The section of the Finance Act 2000 amends the Taxes Act 1988 regarding gift aid payments by companies.
* Simplified point 2: The amendment allows companies to treat gifts to charities as annual payments, simplifying the process of calculating taxes on these gifts.
* Simplified point 3: The amendment also clarifies how to calculate the value of benefits received in consequence of making a payment, such as the right to receive benefits at intervals over a period of less than twelve months.
* Simplified point 4: The section removes certain provisions related to the calculation of charges on income and capital, and replaces them with new provisions that only apply to payments made on or after 1st April 2000.

series.short: "Charitable Giving Overhaul: Streamlined Donations & Tax Relief"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The section removes the requirement for a covenanted donation to be made to a charity in order to qualify for tax relief. Instead, it introduces the concept of a "qualifying donation" which can be made to any charitable organization.
* Simplified point 2: The section also eliminates the need for annual payments and interest to be paid out of profits or gains brought into charge to income tax, making it easier for individuals and companies to make charitable donations without incurring additional tax liabilities.
* Simplified point 3: The section further clarifies that qualifying donations will be treated as a single item for the purposes of tax relief, and that such donations will be subject to the same tax rules as other charitable donations.
* Simplified point 4: The section repeals the provision that allowed for covenanted subscriptions, which were previously available as an alternative form of charitable giving.
* Simplified point 5: The section provides that any deeds of covenant executed before 6th April 2000 will continue to be governed by the previous tax rules, but that any amounts payable under those deeds on or after that date will be subject to the new tax rules.

series.short: "Tax Relief for Charitable Gifts in Poor Countries Under the Finance Act 1998"
series.text:
* The extract simplifies and explains how gifts of money for relief in poor countries can qualify for tax relief under the Finance Act 1998.
* It removes certain restrictions on gifts made before 6th April 2000 and introduces new rules for gifts made on or after that date.
* Gifts must meet certain requirements to qualify for tax relief, such as being made to a charity or community amateur sports club.
* The definition of "relevant gift" is expanded to include gifts that would meet the requirements of the Finance Act 1990, but for certain exceptions.

series.short: "Charitable Donations of Shares and Securities: Tax Benefits and Exemptions"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This law allows individuals and companies to donate shares and securities to charities without paying taxes on the gains.
* Simplified point 2: The market value of the donated shares and securities will determine the amount of the allowable deduction.
* Simplified point 3: If the donor receives any benefits in return for the donation, the deduction will be reduced by the value of those benefits.
* Simplified point 4: Companies that carry on life assurance business are exempt from this law, but they can still deduct the incidental costs of making the donation.
* Simplified point 5: The definition of "qualifying investment" includes shares, securities, units in authorized unit trusts, shares in open-ended investment companies, and interests in offshore funds.
* Simplified point 6: The market value of the qualifying investment is determined for the purposes of this section as for the purposes of the 1992 Act.
* Simplified point 7: This law only applies to disposals made on or after 6th April 2000 for individuals and on or after 1st April 2000 for companies.

series.short: "UK Trust Law: Tax-Exempt Gifts to Charities"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This law allows gifts to charities from certain trusts without incurring tax liabilities.
* Simplified point 2: The law applies only to qualifying income arising under a UK trust, given to a charity in the year of assessment, and excess income is rateably apportioned between sources.
* Simplified point 3: Charities include bodies mentioned in Section 507 of the Taxes Act 1988.
* Simplified point 4: Qualifying income refers to income that can be accumulated, paid at the discretion of the trustees, or income of persons other than the trustees before distribution.
* Simplified point 5: Residency requirements for trustees are defined in Section 110 of the Finance Act 1989.
* Simplified point 6: The law takes effect on or after April 6, 2000.

series.short: "Tax Exemption for Charitable Loans: No Tax on Interest Earned"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: Loans to charities are excluded from being considered settlements for tax purposes.
* Simplified point 2: This means that individuals who lend money to charities without receiving any interest or other forms of consideration will not be subject to tax on the interest earned from those loans.
* Simplified point 3: The provision applies to both pre-existing and new loans made on or after April 6, 2200.
* Simplified point 4: The definition of "charity" used in this section is the same as the one defined in Section 44 of the Taxes Act 1988.

series.short: "Charity Tax Exemptions in the UK: Law and Limits"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This law allows certain charities to be exempt from paying tax on their income.
* Simplified point 2: The exemption applies if the charity's gross income for the relevant period does not exceed a certain limit, or if the charity had a reasonable expectation that its gross income would not exceed that limit.
* Simplified point 3: The limit varies depending on the length of the period, but it is generally around £5,000 to £50,000.
* Simplified point 4: The law defines "charity" as any body of people or trust established for charitable purposes only.
* Simplified point 5: The law applies to the year 2000-01 and subsequent years of assessment, or to accounting periods beginning on or after April 1st, 2000, for charities that are companies.

series.short: "Employee Share Ownership Plans: New Relief for Transfers of Shares"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This extract of the Finance Act 2000 introduces a new relief for transfers of shares to employee share ownership plans (ESOPs).
* Simplified point 2: The relief allows for roll-over relief on the transfer of shares to an approved ESOP, meaning that any gains made on the transfer will be exempt from capital gains tax.
* Simplified point 3: The Schedule 7C inserted into the Taxation of Chargeable Gains Act 1992 provides the details of the relief and its conditions.
* Simplified point 4: The relief is intended to encourage employees to acquire shares in their company through an ESOP, which can help them become shareholders and have a stake in the company's success.

series.short: "Tax Provisions on Approved Profit-Sharing Schemes Phased Out by 2003"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The provision phases out approved profit-sharing schemes under Schedule 9 of the Taxes Act 1988, effective from April 6, 2001.
* Simplified point 2: Applications for approval of such schemes must be submitted before April 6, 2001, or they will not be considered.
* Simplified point 3: Existing approved profit-sharing schemes continue to apply until December 31, 2002.
* Simplified point 4: The provision amends Section 186 of the Taxes Act 1988 to limit its scope to appropriations made before January 1, 2003.

series.short: "Tax Relief Phase-Out for Trustee Payments: Complex Rules for Different Time Periods"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section phases out corporation tax relief for payments to trustees of approved profit-sharing schemes.
* Simplified point 2: The relief is phased out over time, with different rules applying depending on when the payments were made. Payments made before April 2002 are not eligible for relief, while payments made between March 2000 and April 2002 have certain conditions that must be met in order to qualify for relief.

series.short: "Approved Profit Sharing Scheme Allows Trustees to Appropriate Shares to Participants Despite Previous Free Share Awards."
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This clause allows the trustees of an approved profit sharing scheme to appropriate shares to participants, even if some participants have already received free shares under the same scheme in the same tax year.
* Simplified point 2: The clause also ensures that individuals who would have received free shares but failed to meet certain performance conditions (as defined in Schedule 8 to the Finance Act 2000) are still eligible for the award of shares under the scheme.
* Simplified point 3: The definition of "free shares" and "relevant share plan" is provided for the purposes of this clause, and a "connected company" is defined as a company that is related to the grantor through control or ownership.

series.short: "Profit Sharing Scheme Restrictions on Share Types and Dividends"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The legislation restricts the types of shares that can be included in profit sharing schemes, specifically prohibiting shares in employer companies or companies under common control.
* Simplified point 2: The legislation requires that scheme shares not be subject to certain restrictions related to dividends or assets on a winding-up of the company, except for restrictions that apply to all other ordinary shares in the same company.
* Simplified point 3: The legislation applies to profit sharing schemes approved under Schedule 9 to the Taxes Act 1988, and came into force on March 21, 2000, but does not affect shares acquired before that date by the trustees of such schemes.

series.short: "Finance Act 2000 Changes to Approved Profit Sharing Schemes"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Finance Act 2000 adds new conditions for approved profit sharing schemes, specifically regarding loan arrangements.
* Simplified point 2: The scheme must not provide for loans to employees, nor can it be associated with any loan provisions. If the Board is no longer satisfied with these conditions, they can withdraw their approval of the scheme.
* Simplified point 3: The changes introduced by the Finance Act 2000 will apply to both existing and new profit sharing schemes, and will be effective as of March 21st, 2000.

series.short: "Tax Relief Exemptions for Employee Share Ownership Trusts in the UK"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The extract states that there is no claim for relief under certain sections of the Taxation of Chargeable Gains Act 1992 for disposals of shares made on or after April 6th, 2001.
* Simplified point 2: This means that employees who own shares through an employee share ownership trust cannot use roll-over relief to avoid paying taxes on any gains made from the disposal of those shares if the disposal occurs on or after April 6th, 2001.

series.short: ```Transferring Shares from ESOT to ESOP Made Easier```
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The section of the Finance Act 2000 simplifies the process of transferring shares from an Employee Share Ownership Trust (ESOT) to the trustees of an Employee Share Ownership Plan (ESOP).
* Simplified point 2: The section defines "qualifying transfers" and sets out the conditions under which such transfers can be made without triggering a chargeable event.

series.short: "Tax Relief for Employee Pension Contributions"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the legislation allows for relief from tax on gains from share options for employees who contribute to their employer's pension scheme.
* Simplified point 2: The relief is available when the employee enters into an agreement with their employer to recover the contributions made to the pension scheme, or when the employee makes an election to transfer the liability for the contributions to the employer.
* Simplified point 3: The amount of relief available is the total of any amounts recovered or met in respect of the gain, up to the amount of the gain on which the employee is chargeable to tax under Section 135.
* Simplified point 4: The relief is given by way of deduction from the amount of the gain on which the employee is chargeable to tax.
* Simplified point 5: The agreements and elections referred to in this section must be approved by the Inland Revenue under paragraph 3B of Schedule 1 to the Contributions and Benefits Act.

series.short: "UK Tax Changes on Employment Benefits and Education/Training Expenses"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The text describes changes to the UK's Finance Act of 2000 regarding employment benefits and education/training funded by employers.
* Simplified point 2: The changes aim to simplify the process of including certain types of education and training expenses as part of an employee's taxable income.
* Simplified point 3: The text introduces new sections 200E to 200H to the Finance Act of 2000, which outline the conditions under which employers can provide education and training to their employees without including the costs as part of the employee's taxable income.
* Simplified point 4: These new sections specify that certain types of education and training are eligible for inclusion in the scheme, and that the employer must make certain contributions to the costs of the education or training in order for the expenses to be excluded from the employee's taxable income.
* Simplified point 5: The text also includes provisions related to cars available for private use and the provision of services through an intermediary.

series.short: "Entrepreneurial Tax Reliefs: Incentivizing Startups & Growth"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: Enterprise incentives - The UK government is providing incentives for entrepreneurs to start and grow their businesses through the Enterprise Management Incentives scheme. This includes tax relief on shares granted after the passage of the Finance Act 2000.
* Simplified point 2: Corporate Venturing Scheme - The UK government is also offering a Corporate Venturing Scheme to encourage companies to invest in new businesses. This includes tax relief on disposals of business assets made on or after 6th April 2000.
* Simplified point 3: Taper Relief - The UK government is providing taper relief for gains on disposals of business assets made on or after 6th April 2000. This reduces the amount of tax payable on these gains based on the length of time the assets have been held.
* Simplified point 4: Venture Capital Trusts - The UK government is offering tax reliefs for investors in Venture Capital Trusts (VCTs) who invest in small companies. This includes tax relief on disposals of VCT shares made on or after 6th April 2000.
* Simplified point 5: EIS and SEIS - The UK government is offering tax reliefs for investors in Enterprise Investment Schemes (EIS) and Social Entrepreneurship Investment Schemes (SEIS) who invest in small companies. This includes tax relief on disposals of EIS and SEIS shares made on or after 6th April 2000.

series.short: "Finance Act 2000: Research and Development Tax Relief Guidelines"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the Finance Act 2000 defines and provides guidelines for research and development (R&D) for tax purposes.
* Simplified point 2: The act establishes a new definition of R&D for tax purposes, outlines how the tax relief will be given, and includes supplementary provisions.
* Simplified point 3: The tax relief is available for accounting periods starting on or after April 1, 2000, and the schedule provides for entitlement to relief, the manner of giving effect to the relief, and supplementary provisions.
* Simplified point 4: The act also includes consequential amendments related to the changes made to the definition of R&D.

series.short: Small Business Tax Incentives: Streamlined Allowances for Enterprises
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This extract of the legislation allows small or medium-sized enterprises to claim 40% first year allowances on expenditure incurred after July 2nd, 1998.
* Simplified point 2: The legislation makes changes to the definition of "small company" or "small business" in sections 22(3C)(a), (3CA)(a), and (3D)(a) of the Capital Allowances Act 1990, replacing them with "small or medium-sized enterprise".
* Simplified point 3: The amendments in this subsection are of nomenclature only, meaning they do not change the substance of the law but rather update the language used to describe it.

series.short: "UK Government's ICT Investment Incentives for Small Businesses"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government introduced first-year allowances for small enterprises to encourage investment in information and communication technology (ICT).
* Simplified point 2: This policy allows small businesses to claim tax relief on expenses related to ICT equipment and software purchases made between April 2000 and March 2003.
* Simplified point 3: The policy defines eligible equipment and software categories, including computers, peripherals, wireless devices, and software.
* Simplified point 4: The policy excludes certain types of equipment and software, such as computerized control or management systems, from the definition of eligible assets.
* Simplified point 5: The Treasury has the power to make orders to further define or add equipment descriptions to the policy.

series.short: Small Business Tax Law: Streamlined Capital Allowance Claims for Small Enterprises
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This law allows small businesses to claim capital allowances on expenses incurred for the purpose of their trade.
* Simplified point 2: The law defines a "small enterprise" as one that meets certain criteria related to size and ownership, and it establishes rules for determining whether a company is a member of a large or medium-sized group.
* Simplified point 3: The law provides that a company can be considered a small enterprise even if it is part of a larger group, as long as it meets certain conditions related to its financial years and accounting practices.
* Simplified point 4: The law includes provisions for how to determine whether a company is a member of a large or medium-sized group, and it specifies the meaning of certain terms used in the section.

series.short: "Repeal of Notification Requirements for Certain Tax Provisions in the Finance Act 1994"
series.text:
* The extract repeals the notification requirements for certain tax provisions in the Finance Act 1994.
* Specifically, it removes the need for notifications under sections 118(1)-(5) and (7)-(9) of the Finance Act 1994.
* It also replaces the reference to "the provisions mentioned in subsection (2) above" with references to sections 25(1) and 44(4) of the Capital Allowances Act 1990 and the Finance Act 1971, respectively.
* The changes apply to chargeable periods starting on or after April 1, 2000.

series.short: Finance Act 2000 Lease Asset Write-Down Allowances
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the Finance Act 2000 deals with the write-down allowances for leased assets and inexpensive cars.
* Simplified point 2: The section amends the Capital Allowances Act 1990 by removing certain provisions related to leased assets and inexpensive cars, effective for chargeable periods ending on or after a specified date.
* Simplified point 3: The section also introduces new rules for treating excess qualifying expenditure as capital expenditure, subject to certain conditions.
* Simplified point 4: The "relevant date" for the purpose of the section is April 6, 2000 for income tax and April 1, 2000 for corporation tax, but a person can elect to use April 6, 2001 or April 1, 2001 instead.

series.short: UK Government Allows Non-Resident Companies to Claim Capital Allowances on Machinery and Plants
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government is allowing non-resident companies to claim capital allowances on machinery and plants.
* Simplified point 2: The legislation provides for the reduction of qualifying use of machinery and plants in certain situations, and allows for the deeming of capital expenditure incurred on the provision of machinery or plants.
* Simplified point 3: The legislation also makes modifications to the existing law regarding overseas life insurance companies and their assets.
* Simplified point 4: The section 81 of the Capital Allowances Act 1990 will now apply to cases where an asset or part of an asset held by an overseas life insurance company ceases to be within one category and comes within another.
* Simplified point 5: The section 53 of the Capital Allowances Act 1990 has been amended to remove the requirement that the equipment lessee must be within the charge to tax, and to substitute "paragraph" for "paragraphs (bb) and".

series.short: "Exclusion of Certain Animals from Capital Allowances Under Part II of the Finance Act 2000"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This part of the legislation excludes certain types of animals from being eligible for capital allowances under Part II of the Finance Act 2000.
* Simplified point 2: The legislation specifically targets production animals, such as livestock, and shares in these animals, making them ineligible for capital allowances.
* Simplified point 3: The legislation also makes changes to the way Schedule 5 of the Taxes Act 1988 treats farmed animals for the purpose of Case I of Schedule D, allowing for more flexible treatment of animals kept singly or in herds.
* Simplified point 4: The amendments made by this section of the legislation are deemed to have always had effect, retroactively applying the changes to previous years.

series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Finance Act 2000 allows for court orders to obtain documents related to suspected serious tax fraud cases.
* Simplified point 2: The law empowers judges to require individuals to deliver documents believed to be in their possession, and failure to comply can result in penalties.
* Simplified point 3: The provision applies to both individuals and businesses, and covers a wide range of documents, including electronic records.
* Simplified point 4: The law includes measures to protect the privacy of individuals and confidentiality of certain documents.

series.short: The Finance Act 2000 Amends Search Warrant Procedures for Tax Investigations in the UK
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Finance Act 2000 makes changes to search warrant procedures for tax investigations in the UK.
* Simplified point 2: The changes include requiring the Board to have reasonable grounds for believing that using the procedure under Section 20BA would seriously prejudice the investigation before approving an application for a warrant.
* Simplified point 3: The changes also expand the definition of "information" that can be seized to include data stored on computers, and clarify that items subject to legal privilege cannot be seized.
* Simplified point 4: The act also allows for petitions for the issue of warrants in respect of multiple premises situated in different sheriffdoms to be made to the sheriff for any of the premises.

series.short: "UK Government Finance Regulations: Managing Debt and National Savings Certificates"
series.text:

* Simplified point 5: Automatic roll-over of national savings certificates can occur every five years, allowing for continued investment at fixed rates or with index-linking.
